div.head: Molding sulfur
div.ab: Sulfur is made beautiful mixed with soot black or pulverized bloodstone, which makes it harder and stronger. Having let it melt well until it becomes liquid, like oil, mix it with verdigris, and you m will cast in plaster very cleanly a lizard, or something else.

left-top You must not cast it until it is well cooled & has lost all of its lumps & bubbles, and it has settled down & become even like [illegible] water. The soot black gives it a fine luster & makes it neater. The most beautiful yellow sulfur must be used, for the greyish & lively sulfur is not good. Do not cast in wind & cold, for it would become porous.

Cimolee, otherwise known as fullerâ€™s earth, which prepares cloth, is excellent for molding hollow or in relief; & if you want to reheat it, it must first be warm, & reheat it gently on low, indirect flame, & little by little, otherwise it would crack. Put the figure for reheating in a pot in an oven, or in a covered oven. It is very malleable, clean & fine. You can make a hollow for animals of cimolee & cast lead in it.
left-middle The work needs to be dry for 4 or 5 days before you reheat it. When you mold & make a hollow in cimolee, do not press too hard, but gently, for it would crack.

The whitest & finest is the best. And when the cavity is quite clean, as that of sulfur or baked cimolee, it is made very neatly. You can give it one or two layers of white with a border of gold to imitate alabaster. And after applying the white, you may burnish it with a tooth. But in order for it to be burnished, one needs to soak the lead white with egg white & peelings from the fig tree. Or better, varnish your work with white varnish. In addition when you are molding with paper, as it starts to dry, burnish from the back with the tooth.

Mountain plaster is greyer, and the the one from the region of Albi is whiter. It must be heated over a closed fire, such as a reverberatory furnace or fours de barbiers. And the best to work with is the most recently heated one. It must be finely ground on marble. After preparing your hollow mold with sulfur or something else, & oiling it, & investing with a circle, temper not too thickly your plaster with water, & stir it well with your finger, and if it makes lumps, throw in more powder of the said plaster & [illegible] grind it with your finger until +
left-bottom + it makes no more lumps. Then immediately throw in & sprinkle plaster powder & leave to set well, then scrape the powder off.
